results.headline: East Coast Bollywood
results.summary_short: “Ta Ra Rum Pum” may take place entirely in New York, but that doesn’t stop it from being a classic example of Bollywood family values.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Ta Ra Rum Pum

results.headline: Transdimensional Romance
results.summary_short: “The Invisible,” the latest recycling of foreign-grown frights, shows less interest in horror than in healing.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Invisible

results.headline: A Personal Portrait of War
results.summary_short: Lance Cpl. José Antonio Gutiérrez, the first American soldier killed in the invasion of Iraq, is the subject of this nonfiction film.
results.display_title: The Short Life of Jose Antonio Gutierrez

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Short Life of Jose Antonio Gutierrez

results.headline: Digging for Clams and Difficult Answers
results.summary_short: This minutely observed period piece, set in 1976, has the brave, mournful tone of a Bruce Springsteen song set in Billy Joel territory.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Diggers

results.headline: An Autistic Woman’s Lessons for the Cynical
results.summary_short: “Snow Cake” partly camouflages the banality of its concept with its meticulous performances.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Snow Cake

results.headline: Midlife Harmonies
results.summary_short: “Sing Now or Forever Hold Your Peace,” a “Big Chill” for today’s 36-year-olds, aims to put wisdom and unrelenting quippery in a seaside light.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Wedding Weekend

results.headline: The Disciples of André, Monsieur Literary Dash
results.summary_short: Ornamented with passages from Racine and long, earnest conversations at restaurant tables, Emmanuel Bourdieu’s “Poison Friends” is atmospherically and unmistakably French.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Poison Friends

results.headline: Glimpsing the Future (and a Babe)
results.summary_short: In “Next,”  Nicolas Cage plays a guy who can see into the future. It’s too bad that Mr. Cage couldn’t tap into those powers to save himself from another bad choice in roles.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Next

results.headline: Wrestling With Action
results.summary_short: “The Condemned” is tailor-made for those who like their violence multifaceted and their women monosyllabic.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Condemned

results.headline: Victories Beyond the Basketball Court
results.summary_short: Short, sweet and sentimental, “Something to Cheer About” tells the story of the first all-black high school basketball team to win a state championship.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Something to Cheer About

results.headline: ... Leads to a Game of Wits in a Sinister Underworld
results.summary_short: The surfaces gleam as luxuriously in Johnnie To’s exemplary gangster thriller “Triad Election” as those in a similarly slicked-up Hollywood film, but the blood on the floor here seems stickier.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Election 2

results.headline: A Low-Key Gangster’s Rise in Sunny Hong Kong ...
results.summary_short: “Election,” the first installment in Johnnie To’s two-film Hong Kong gangland serial, is a densely plotted, pulpy procedural.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Election

results.headline: Into the Shadowy World of Sex With Animals
results.summary_short: “Zoo” is, to a large extent, about the rhetorical uses of beauty.  It is, rather more coyly, also about a man who died after having sex with a stallion.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Zoo

results.headline: A Famously Sharp Eye, and Appetite, for Artistic Masterpieces
results.summary_short: “The Collector,” a documentary about influential New York art gallery owner Allan Stone, is fascinating for its nonstop parade of significant 20th-century art.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Collector

results.headline: Wanted: A Third Party to Complete Love Triangle
results.summary_short: If you love to hate the superrich, “The Valet” is a sinfully delicious bonbon.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Valet

results.headline: Banished to the Country, a Too-Good Cop Finds an Action-Movie Parody
results.summary_short: Think of “Hot Fuzz,” a British parody of Hollywood-style action flicks, as “The Full Monty” blown to smithereens.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Hot Fuzz

results.headline: A Portraitist’s Grandson Creates Her Portrait on Film
results.summary_short: The fascinating documentary “Alice Neel” illuminates history while also demonstrating how an artist’s style reveals his or her personality.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Alice Neel

results.headline: A Mixed-Up Son of ‘The Graduate’
results.summary_short: The meek, mopey comedy “In the Land of Women” is the film equivalent of a sensitive emo band with one foot in alternative rock and the other in the squishy pop mainstream.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of In the Land of Women

results.headline: Innocence or Experience? An American Tale
results.summary_short: Without standing on a soapbox “Stephanie Daley” suggests a tragic gender gap between men who judge and women who feel.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Stephanie Daley

results.headline: Playing a Game of Cat and Mouse Without Breaking a Sweat
results.summary_short: “Fracture” offers the spectacle of that crafty scene stealer Anthony Hopkins mixing it up with that equally cunning screen nibbler Ryan Gosling.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Fracture
